cards.back: A physical quantity that varies with one or more independent variables (typically time).
A device or process that transforms an input signal into an output signal.
A continuous-time signal ‚Äî defined for all real values of t. Parentheses = continuous.
A discrete-time signal ‚Äî defined only for integer values of n. Brackets = discrete.
A system that converts one type of physical signal to another (e.g., microphone: sound ‚Üí voltage).

1. Speech (acoustic)
2. ECG (electrical)
3. Temperature over time
4. Stock prices
5. Video

cards.front: What are the three main system connection types?
cards.back:
1. Cascade (series) ‚Äî output of one to input of next
2. Parallel ‚Äî same input to multiple systems
3. Feedback ‚Äî output fed back to input

cards.front: Why are electrical signals preferred for processing?
cards.back:
Because they are:
1. Easy to amplify and filter
2. Easy to transmit (wired/wireless)
3. Easy to store (digital memory)

cards.front: What is a 2D signal? Give an example.
cards.back:
A signal with two independent variables.

Example: Image I(x,y) where x and y are spatial coordinates.
